results.title: The Things of life = Les choses de la vie
results.creator_credit: Fida Cinematografica, Jean Bolvary, Raymond Danon, Roland Girard, Claude Sautet and Lira Films
results.brief_description: Pierre (Michel Piccoli) has a collision at a roadside intersection and as he battles for his life on the way to hospital, he reflects back on his life, particularly his relationships with his wife (Lea Massari) and his mistress (Romy Schneider). Sautet is a master of a refined form of bourgeois melodrama in which protagonists are jolted out of security and forced to re-examine the meaning of their lives and the value of marriage, family and love. In many ways, “Les Choses de la Vie”, made in 1969, takes the departures allowed for by the radical events of May 1968 not as a means for subverting aesthetics, but for examining the shifts this caused for middle-class morality and values. Pierre is torn by the duties he feels towards love and his duties as a father and husband to his son and wife. His recollections are all part of attempting to reconcile his conflicting desires with the truth of his own mortality. The film is based on the novel by Paul Guimard and the elegant film score is by Philippe Sarde. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Thin man
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Cosmopolitan, Hunt Stromberg and W S. Van Dyke
results.brief_description: Dashiell Hammett’s 1932 detective novel, “The thin man”, was a best- seller sought by every major Hollywood studio. MGM won out and the result is a crime thriller combined with high comedy. As Nick and Nora Charles, the wisecracking darlings of society, William Powell and Myrna Loy made history portraying two sophisticates who are not only married but also very much in love, also stars Cesar Romero.

results.title: The Texas chainsaw massacre = The Texas chain saw massacre
results.brief_description: Loosely based on the grizzly exploits of American serial killer Ed Gein (also a model for Norman Bates in “Psycho”), Tobe Hooper’s “The Texas chain saw massacre” rightly deserves its place as a horror classic. Five teenagers travelling through Texas (two of them brother and sister investigating the mysterious desecration of their grandfather’s grave), pick up a creepy hitchhiker and find themselves embroiled in a macabre and nightmarish reverse of southern hospitality. From its eerie opening images to its shocking finale, “The Texas chain saw massacre’ was initially considered a cheap drive-in exploitation film but, through strong critical appraisal, went on to be screened as part of the director’s fortnight at Cannes and the American Museum of Modern Art now has a print of it in its permanent collection. Cast includes Marilyn Burns, Allen Danziger and Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface. Please note: special features are contained on disk two.

results.title: The Terror of Tiny Town
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures Corporation, Principal Productions, Abe Meyer, Bert Sternbach, Jed Buell and Sam Newfield
results.brief_description: This movie has all the classic elements usually found in westerns of the 1930’s - 1950’s. The dashing hero, the fair damsel in need of rescuing, the despised villain, singing, dancing, and the big chase scene. It’s all here. The one thing that separates this movie from any other western is the cast. 100% midgets, the entire movie is cast with actors under the height of 4 feet 8 inches, with a couple of fellas who just might make three feet. You haven’t seen a true chase scene until you see a group of guys chasing each other on Shetland ponies.

results.title: The Tenant
results.creator_credit: Andrew Braunsberg, Roman Polanski and Marianne Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Richard Topor, “The Tenant” is a psychological horror film by Roman Polanski which can also be read as a deeply disturbed personal work about a man’s disintegration in the face of death and tragedy. (There are obvious parallels to be drawn by the mental disintegration of the film’s main character, Trelkovsky - played by Polanski himself - to the crisis suffered by the director when his wife and unborn child were brutally slaughtered by the infamous Charles Manson cult). Polanski’s work from the beginning of his career has seen him play mischievously and surrealistically with the themes of mental illness, hauntings and transvestitism, but in “The Tenant”, the whole world which Trelkovsky inhabits seems to be riddled with varying degrees of evil and repressed violence. He is a new tenant in an old Baroque Parisian hotel and the last occupant in his room attempted suicide by jumping from the building. Trelkovsky meets her on the day of her death: the memory of her anguished screaming will reverberate with him for the rest of his life. The cast includes Isabelle Adjani, Melvyn Douglas, Shelley Winters and Lila Kedrova, and the sombre lighting and cinematography is by noted Swedish cinematographer, Sven Nykvist. As always, Polanski proves an effective and imaginative master of the horror genre. Note: “The Tenant” is a USA/French co-production in which the French actors are dubbed into English.

results.title: The Tao of Steve
results.creator_credit: Thunderhead Productions, Anthony Bregman and Jenniphr Goodman
results.brief_description: Santa Fe primary school teacher Dex (Donal Logue) is a success with the ladies and he owes it all to Steve - Steve Austin, Steve McQueen, Steve McGarrett - the prototypical cool American male, he never has to impress the women but always gets the ladies. Dex and his entourage of single male friends (one is happily married), subscribe to the tao of Steve, valuing such ideals as suppressing that which you desire and doing something excellent in front of the ladies. Dex’s comfortable, philandering existence is thrown into turmoil when he meets Syd (Greer Goodman) - a conquest from his thinner, college years - whom, to his surprise, he discovers he is falling in love with, causing him to question the code by which he has lived his life thus far. A surprise sleeper at the 2000 Sundance Film Festival, Goodman’s directorial debut saw Donal Logue awarded with a Special Jury Prize.

results.title: The Taming of the shrew
results.brief_description: Petruchio, a poor gentleman from Verona, finds a rich but shrewish wife, Kate in Padua. Their stormy relationship takes a different turn when Petruchio wagers that Kate is the most obedient of wives. Stars Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Burton, Cyril Cusack, Michael Hordern and Michael York.

creators_other.name: Victorian Council for Children's Films and Television

results.title: The Talk of the town
results.brief_description: This zany romantic comedy, nominated for six Academy Awards stars Cary Grant as Leopold Dilg, a prison escapee who hides out in the home of schoolteacher Nora, played by Jean Arthur. Leopold enlists the help of Nora to try and convince her summer tenant, Supreme Court candidate Michael Lightcap (Ronald Colman), that Dilig was falsely imprisoned on the charge of arson. As the charming and persuasive fugitive and conservative lawyer share living arrangements they also find themselves sharing a growing affection for the beautiful schoolteacher.

results.title: The Tale of Ruby Rose
results.brief_description: Set amid the austere beauty of Tasmania’s mountainous landscape, The Tale of Ruby Rose is a portrait of a family alone in the wilderness and one woman’s strength to overcome an intense fear of the dark. Driven by her husband’s indifference to her fear, Ruby makes the hazardous trip across the mountains to the village of her birth in the lowlands. There, with her grandmother, she comes to terms with her terror of the elements. Cast: Melita Jurisic, Chris Haywood, Rod Zuanic, Martyn Sanderson, Sheila Florance.
